Reading Comprehension Review



Big Problems, Simple Solutions
Ingenious innovations are improving health and well-being in communities around the world. Speakers at recent TED events have shared simple and inexpensive solutions that can solve everyday problems.
LIQUID LENSES
Many people need eyeglasses, but there often aren’t enough eye doctors in the developing world. For example, there’s only one optometrist for every 8 million people in some parts of Africa. Physicist Joshua Silver has a solution: Adjust your own eyeglasses.
Silver invented eyeglasses that have lenses filled with a liquid. You turn a dial on the sides of the glasses to add or subtract the liquid. Adjusting the amount of liquid changes the strength of the lenses, making it easier for people to see better. The glasses cost $19 today, but Silver hopes to get this down to $1 by 2020.
FUEL BRIQUETTES
In the developing world, smoke from indoor cooking kills more than 2 million children each year. In fact, it’s the number one cause of death of children under five. Amy Smith, founder of D-Lab at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), discovered a way to make a safe cooking fuel. The material she uses is also free and plentiful: farm waste.
Smith invented a low-cost device that compresses1 farm waste into fuel briquettes. These briquettes produce smoke that is less dangerous than the smoke from other fuel, such as wood. They also burn hotter and last longer. Farmers can make these briquettes from readily available waste, such as hay in India and corncobs in Ghana. This innovation has an economic benefit, too. Farmers can buy the press for $2 and sell briquettes they don’t use. Smith estimates that this can increase a farmer’s income by $500 a month.
DISASTER SHELTERS
Over 31 million people worldwide lose their homes every year due to natural disasters such as hurricanes and earthquakes. After these disasters, many people live in terrible conditions—in tents or in large arenas with no privacy. Graphic designer Michael McDaniel invented inexpensive, temporary housing for people in these situations.
Called the Reaction Exo, these shelters are small, one-room houses that comfortably hold up to four people. They’re made from a plastic that is strong, recyclable, and super light. In fact, they’re so light that you can lift them by hand. The shelters are very portable2—you can stack them like paper cups to transport them easily. They snap together, so you can make one large shelter with several rooms. McDaniel hopes that his invention will provide an affordable solution to help people rebuild their lives after a natural disaster.
1compress: v. presses together
2portable: adj. movable, capable of being carried or moved around

items.q: What is the purpose of this passage?
options: to describe three inventions used to solve common problems
to compare three inventions and see which is the best
to describe how inventors are able to come up with unique ideas

options: In the developing world, smoke from indoor cooking kills more than 2 million children each year.
Ingenious innovations are improving health and well-being in communities around the world.

items.q: Which sentence from the passage gives a solution?
options: Many people need eyeglasses, but there often aren’t enough eye doctors in the developing world.
Amy Smith, founder of D-Lab at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), discovered a way to make a safe cooking fuel.
After these disasters, many people live in terrible conditions—in tents or in large arenas with no privacy.

items.q: In the Liquid Lenses section, what happens when people add or subtract liquid?
options: The lenses change shape so people can see better.
Their glasses change in size and become more comfortable to wear.
They lenses become darker to protect people’s eyes from sunlight.

items.q: How do liquid lenses compare to regular glasses?
options: Liquid lenses can be adjusted by the wearer.
Liquid lenses help people see better than regular glasses.
Liquid lenses are easier to transport.

items.q: In the Fuel Briquettes section, which happens first?
options: Farmers sell their extra briquettes.
Farmers collect natural waste and use a press to make the briquettes.
The briquettes produce some smoke but are hotter and last longer than traditional cooking fuel.

items.q: About how many homes are lost to natural disasters each year?
options: 2 million
5 million
31 million

items.q: Which word does NOT describe the Reaction Exos?
options: lightweight
inexpensive
complicated

items.q: What does the number 8 million refer to?
options: the number of Africans per 1 optometrist
the number of Exos that have been built
the number of children killed by smoke

items.q: According to the passage, how are the three inventions similar?
options: They are all easy to recycle.
They improve people’s wellbeing.
They use only natural materials.

Reading Comprehension Extension



Wind-up Radio

In 1991, Trevor Bayliss saw a TV program about the spread of AIDS in Africa. The show said that because many people there did not have TVs, radios, or even electricity, it was difficult to educate people about the disease. Before the show had finished, Bayliss was in his workshop, working on his most famous invention.

Bayliss’s idea was to build a radio that didn’t need electricity and could be used by people wherever they lived. By using a part from a music box, Bayliss came up with a prototype for a radio that would be powered by a wind-up mechanism, much like a toy car.

Initially, no one wanted to help Bayliss produce his radios on a mass scale. But after he appeared on the popular British TV program Tomorrow’s World in 1994, he was contacted by investors. In 1996, Bayliss was able to form a company called Freeplay Energy to produce his radios.

Since then, his Wind-up Radio has been widely used, not just in Africa, but also in many Western countries. Bayliss was awarded the 1996 World Vision Award, and in the same year, he met Queen Elizabeth II and Nelson Mandela.

Following his success, Bayliss has sought to help other inventors by setting up the Trevor Bayliss Foundation. The aim is to assist and encourage inventors and engineers who may have difficulties finding investors to support their ideas. In this way, Bayliss hopes that more remarkable inventions like his Wind-up Radio will find their way into the lives of people who need them.

items.q: What gave Trevor Bayliss the idea for his invention?
options: his experiences traveling in Africa
the problems he had with his own radio
a TV show about AIDS in Africa

items.q: What problem was Bayliss’s invention designed to solve?
options: the problem of getting information to people who had no radios or TVs
the problem of providing a cheap form of entertainment to poor people
the problem of producing environmentally friendly radios

items.q: Which of the following statements is NOT true about the Wind-up Radio?
options: Bayliss built the original prototype using a part from a music box.
Bayliss’s first prototype needed electricity, but later he added a wind-up mechanism.
The Wind-up Radio is powered in the same way as many toy cars.

items.q: How did Bayliss find investors for his radio?
options: He heard about an investment company when he was watching TV.
A friend introduced him to a possible investor.
He appeared on a popular TV show.

items.q: What was the name of Bayliss’s company?
options: Tomorrow’s World
Freeplay Energy
World Vision

items.q: When did Bayliss meet Nelson Mandela?
options: It’s not stated in the article.

items.q: Which of the following is NOT true about Trevor Bayliss?
options: He formed a company in 1996.
He won the World Vision award in 1994.
He met Queen Elizabeth II in 1996.

items.q: What is the aim of the Trevor Bayliss Foundation?
options: to raise awareness about AIDS around the world
to provide support for inventors and their inventions
to produce more Wind-up Radios for the poorest people in the world

items.q: What does on a mass scale mean in paragraph 3?
options: in large numbers
in a quick way
of better quality

items.q: What does setting up mean in paragraph 5?
options: thinking of
increasing
establishing

items.q: Before the show had finished, Bayliss was in his workshop, working on his most famous invention.
options: Bayliss was so excited about his idea that he started working on it immediately.
Bayliss didn’t have much time to make his invention, so he started immediately.

items.q: . . . after he appeared on the popular British TV program Tomorrow’s World in 1994, he was contacted by investors.
options: The investors watched the program and thought Bayliss’s invention could make money.
Bayliss met some investors who were appearing on the same TV program.

items.q: . . . his Wind-up Radio has been widely used, not just in Africa, but also in many Western countries.
options: There are some people in Western countries who do not have access to electricity.
The Wind-up Radio is useful; even for those who have access to electricity.

items.q: Bayliss was awarded the 1996 World Vision Award, and in the same year, he met Queen Elizabeth II and Nelson Mandela.
options: The Wind-up Radio made more money than any other radio in 1996.
Many people thought that the Wind-up Radio was a fantastic invention.

items.q: Following his success, Bayliss has sought to help other inventors by setting up the Trevor Bayliss Foundation.
options: The Trevor Bayliss Foundation is useful for inventors who don’t have enough money to produce their inventions on a large scale.

sections.passage:
TED Talk Comprehension


Jane Chen—A Warm Embrace that Saves Lives
On one of my first trips to India, I met this young woman, Sevitha, who had just given birth to a tiny premature baby, Rani. She took her baby to the nearest village clinic, and the doctor advised her to take Rani to a city hospital so she could be placed in an incubator. But that hospital was over four hours away, and Sevitha didn’t have the means to get there, so her baby died.
Inspired by this story, and dozens of other similar stories like this, my team and I realized what was needed was a local solution, something that could work without electricity, that was simple enough for a mother or a midwife to use, given that the majority of births still take place in the home. We needed something that was portable, something that could be sterilized and reused across multiple babies, and something ultra-low-cost compared to the $20,000 that an incubator in the U.S. costs.

items.q: How were Jane Chen and her team inspired by Sevitha’s story? a. They thought it was an amazing story. b. It made them want to do something to help. c. They felt Sevitha was an incredible young woman.
In paragraph 1, why did the baby die? a. The doctor didn’t have the required skills. b. Sevitha couldn’t get her baby to the hospital. c. The village clinic’s incubators weren’t working.
According to the second paragraph, what do we know about births in India? a. Most births take place in homes. b. Most babies are born prematurely. c. It is expensive to have babies in India.
Which word does NOT describe Jane Chen’s device? a. simple b. electrical c. inexpensive
That is the primary function of an incubator. . . .
In designing this, we followed a few basic principles. . . .
Over the next five years, we hope to save the lives of almost a million babies. . . .
But the bigger problem is that the ones who do survive grow up with severe, long-term health problems. . . .
